safety_notes: Warm up thoroughly before each strength session to prevent injury
Stay hydrated - drink water before, during, and after workouts
Listen to your body - distinguish between good muscle fatigue and harmful pain
Maintain proper form over heavy weight - quality beats quantity
Allow 48 hours recovery between intense strength sessions for same muscle groups

exercises.name: Dynamic Warm-up Circuit
exercises.description: Prepare body for strength training by activating muscles, increasing blood flow, and improving range of motion
steps: Arm circles: 10 forward, 10 backward with arms extended
Cat-cow stretches: 10 reps, moving through full spinal flexion and extension
Inchworms: 6 reps - walk hands out to plank, walk feet to hands, stand up
Shoulder taps in plank: 20 total (10 per side), maintaining stable core
Bodyweight squats: 12 reps with arms overhead to open shoulders
Jumping jacks: 30 seconds moderate pace
tips: This warm-up should elevate heart rate to 60-70% max
Focus on quality movement - you're preparing muscles for work
If anything feels tight, spend extra time on that movement
By end of warm-up, you should feel loose and energized
exercises.easier: Reduce reps by 30%, skip jumping jacks or substitute marching in place
exercises.harder: Add 5 burpees at the end, or increase jumping jacks to 60 seconds
warnings: Stop if experiencing joint pain
Don't skip warm-up - injury prevention is critical

exercises.name: Push-ups (Standard or Modified)
exercises.description: Compound upper body exercise targeting chest, shoulders, and triceps - foundation for upper body strength
steps: Start in plank position: hands slightly wider than shoulders, body in straight line from head to heels
Engage core by pulling belly button toward spine
Lower body by bending elbows until chest is 2-3 inches from floor (or as low as comfortable)
Keep elbows at 45-degree angle to body, not flared out to 90 degrees
Push through palms to return to starting position
Maintain straight body line throughout - don't let hips sag or pike up
Exhale on push up, inhale on lowering
tips: Full range of motion is more important than high reps
If form breaks down, switch to easier version mid-set
Squeeze glutes and core throughout - this is a full-body exercise
Look slightly ahead of hands, not straight down, to maintain neck alignment
These build strength for everyday pushing movements and running arm drive
exercises.easier: Knee push-ups (knees on ground), or incline push-ups (hands on bench/counter)
exercises.harder: Add 2-second pause at bottom, or elevate feet on bench, or add 2 reps per set
warnings: Stop if experiencing wrist or shoulder pain
Don't let lower back sag - engage core throughout
Avoid if you have acute shoulder injury

exercises.name: Dumbbell Rows (Single Arm)
exercises.description: Build back strength and improve posture - critical for balanced upper body development and running economy
steps: Place left knee and left hand on bench for support, right foot on floor
Hold dumbbell in right hand, arm hanging straight down
Keep back flat and parallel to floor, core engaged
Pull dumbbell up toward hip, driving elbow back and up
Squeeze shoulder blade at top of movement, hold 1 second
Lower dumbbell with control back to starting position
Complete all right arm reps, then switch to left arm
tips: Think 'elbow to sky' - lead the movement with elbow, not hand
Don't rotate torso - keep shoulders square to floor
Pull dumbbell to hip, not toward shoulder
This strengthens muscles used in running arm swing and improves posture
Control the weight on the way down - eccentric phase builds strength
exercises.easier: Use lighter weight (5-8 kg), or do bent-over rows with both arms simultaneously
exercises.harder: Increase weight by 2 kg, add 1-second pause at top, or increase reps to 12
warnings: Stop if experiencing lower back pain - may indicate too heavy or poor form
Keep neck neutral - don't crane head up
Don't round back - maintain flat spine throughout

exercises.name: Overhead Dumbbell Press
exercises.description: Develop shoulder strength and stability - important for overhead activities and athletic performance
equipment: Chair or bench with back support
steps: Sit on bench with back support, feet flat on floor
Hold dumbbells at shoulder height, palms facing forward, elbows at 90 degrees
Engage core and press dumbbells up and slightly inward until arms are fully extended
Dumbbells should nearly touch at top, directly over shoulders
Lower dumbbells with control back to shoulder height
Don't let dumbbells drop below ear level on descent
Keep back against bench - don't arch excessively
tips: Press weight UP, not forward - maintain vertical path
Breathe out on press, in on lowering
Stop just short of locking elbows at top to maintain tension
This builds strength for overhead reaching, swimming, tennis
Strong shoulders improve running posture and reduce fatigue
exercises.easier: Use lighter weight (3-5 kg), or do alternating arms (one at a time)
exercises.harder: Increase weight by 2 kg, do standing overhead press for more core challenge, or add 2 reps
warnings: Stop if experiencing sharp shoulder pain
Don't arch lower back excessively - engage core
Avoid if you have shoulder impingement issues

exercises.name: Plank Hold with Variations
exercises.description: Core stability exercise essential for running efficiency, injury prevention, and overall functional strength
steps: Start in forearm plank: elbows under shoulders, forearms on ground, body in straight line
Engage core by pulling belly button to spine, squeeze glutes
Hold standard plank for 30 seconds, breathing normally
Rest 15 seconds
Hold plank with right arm extended forward for 15 seconds
Rest 15 seconds
Hold plank with left arm extended forward for 15 seconds
Rest and repeat entire sequence
tips: Quality over duration - perfect form for 20 seconds beats sloppy 60 seconds
Don't hold breath - maintain steady breathing throughout
Imagine pulling elbows and toes toward each other to engage core
Strong core directly translates to better running form and faster times
If hips start sagging, drop to knees immediately to maintain quality
exercises.easier: Knee plank (knees on ground), or reduce hold time to 15-20 seconds, or skip arm variations
exercises.harder: Increase hold to 45-60 seconds, add shoulder taps, or do full plank from hands instead of forearms
warnings: Stop if lower back hurts - drop to knees or rest
Don't let hips sag or pike up - maintain straight line
Avoid if you have wrist issues (use forearm version)

exercises.name: Russian Twists
exercises.description: Rotational core exercise to strengthen obliques and improve running stability and power transfer
steps: Sit on floor with knees bent, feet flat, holding weight at chest level
Lean back slightly (45-degree angle) to engage core, keep back straight
Lift feet 2-3 inches off ground (or keep on ground for easier version)
Rotate torso to bring weight toward right side, tapping weight on floor beside hip
Rotate through center to left side, tapping weight on floor beside left hip
That's one rep - continue alternating with controlled movement
Keep chest up and shoulders back throughout
tips: Rotation comes from core/obliques, not just moving arms side to side
Keep lower body stable - legs shouldn't swing with rotation
Breathe rhythmically - don't hold breath
This directly improves your running efficiency on turns and hills
Start lighter than you think - this exercise is deceptively challenging
exercises.easier: Keep feet on ground, use lighter weight or no weight, or reduce reps to 12-15
exercises.harder: Extend legs straighter, use heavier weight (10 kg), or increase reps to 30
warnings: Stop if experiencing lower back pain - may be leaning back too far
Avoid if you have acute lower back issues
Don't jerk or use momentum - control the rotation

exercises.name: Cool-down: Upper Body & Core Stretches
exercises.description: Prevent muscle tightness and promote recovery after strength work
steps: Doorway chest stretch: Place forearm on door frame, step forward until stretch in chest/shoulder, hold 30 seconds each side
Overhead tricep stretch: Reach right arm overhead, bend elbow down back, gently pull elbow with left hand, hold 30 seconds, repeat left arm
Seated spinal twist: Sit cross-legged, place right hand on left knee, twist left, hold 30 seconds, repeat right side
Cat-cow stretch: 10 slow reps on hands and knees
Child's pose: Hold 60 seconds, focus on breathing deeply
Deep breathing: 10 slow breaths - 4 count inhale, 6 count exhale
tips: Stretching is not optional - it's injury prevention and recovery
Never bounce in stretches - hold steady and breathe into them
You should feel gentle pulling, never sharp pain
This is mental recovery time too - reflect on workout quality
Good flexibility supports your yoga practice and running
exercises.easier: Reduce hold times to 15-20 seconds
exercises.harder: Hold stretches for 45-60 seconds, add foam rolling
warnings: Stop any stretch causing sharp pain
Don't force range of motion

exercises.name: Easy Conversational Pace Run
exercises.description: Build aerobic base for half marathon training - foundation for endurance
steps: 5-minute warm-up walk, gradually increasing pace
Begin running at conversational pace (you should be able to speak full sentences)
Target: 30 minutes continuous running at 65-75% max heart rate
Focus on form: midfoot strike, 170-180 steps per minute cadence, relaxed shoulders
If needed, take 1-minute walk breaks every 10 minutes (run-walk method)
Final 5 minutes: gradually slow to walking pace for cool-down
tips: This should feel EASY - building aerobic base requires patience
If you can't hold conversation, slow down
Focus on time on feet, not speed - distance will come
Your current 5K pace is too fast for base building - slow down 30-60 seconds per km
Proper aerobic base prevents injury and improves race performance
exercises.easier: Run-walk intervals: 5 min run, 1 min walk, repeat - or reduce to 20 minutes total
exercises.harder: Increase to 40 minutes continuous, or add 4x30-second pickups at faster pace
warnings: Stop if experiencing sharp joint pain, especially knees or ankles
Stay well-hydrated in early morning runs
Don't run through pain - rest is productive

exercises.name: Post-Run Dynamic Stretching
exercises.description: Maintain flexibility and prevent tightness after running
steps: Walking lunges with twist: 10 per leg - lunge forward, twist toward front leg
Leg swings: 10 forward/back, 10 side-to-side per leg, holding wall for balance
Standing quad stretch: 30 seconds per leg
Standing calf stretch: 30 seconds per leg against wall
Hip flexor stretch: 30 seconds per side in lunge position
Pigeon pose or figure-4 stretch: 30 seconds per side for hip/glute flexibility
Deep breathing: 5 slow breaths to finish
tips: Post-run stretching prevents injury and improves recovery
Focus on hip flexors and calves - these tighten most from running
Stretching when warm (post-run) is more effective than cold stretching
This complements your yoga practice nicely
exercises.easier: Shorter holds (15-20 seconds), or skip dynamic portions and do only static stretches
exercises.harder: Hold stretches 45 seconds each, add foam rolling for IT band and quads
warnings: Never force a stretch into pain
Be careful with hamstring stretches if you have history of pulls

exercises.name: Dynamic Lower Body Warm-up
exercises.description: Activate glutes, hips, and legs before heavy strength work
steps: Glute bridges: 15 reps, squeezing glutes at top
Bodyweight squats: 15 reps, full range of motion
Lateral band walks: 10 steps each direction (if using band), or lateral lunges if no band
High knees: 30 seconds in place
Butt kicks: 30 seconds in place
World's greatest stretch: 5 reps per side (lunge with rotation and overhead reach)
tips: Feel glutes and hips activating - these are your power generators
Lower body warm-up is critical for injury prevention
You should feel warm and loose after this
This prepares you for heavy squats and lunges
exercises.easier: Reduce reps by 50%, skip high knees/butt kicks
exercises.harder: Add resistance band for all movements, increase duration to 10 minutes
warnings: Stop if experiencing knee or hip pain
Don't rush - quality activation is key

exercises.name: Goblet Squats
exercises.description: Fundamental lower body strength exercise targeting quads, glutes, and core - essential for running power
steps: Hold dumbbell vertically at chest level with both hands cupping top end
Stand with feet slightly wider than shoulder-width, toes pointed slightly out
Engage core, chest up, shoulders back
Lower down by pushing hips back and bending knees, keeping weight at chest
Descend until thighs are parallel to floor (or as deep as comfortable with good form)
Drive through full foot (not just toes) to stand back up
Squeeze glutes at top, fully extend hips
Keep knees tracking over toes throughout - don't let them cave inward
tips: The weight at chest helps keep torso upright - use this to your advantage
Think 'sit back into chair' not just 'bend knees'
Push through heels and midfoot equally - should feel entire foot engaged
This builds the leg strength needed for hill running and late-race surges
Keep chest up by focusing eyes on point 6 feet ahead
Squats are the king of lower body exercises - master this movement
exercises.easier: Reduce weight (5-8 kg), or reduce depth (half squats), or box squats (sit to bench)
exercises.harder: Increase weight by 2-4 kg, add 2-second pause at bottom, or increase reps to 15
warnings: Stop if experiencing knee pain (muscle burn is OK, joint pain is not)
Don't let knees cave inward - push them out actively
Keep heels on ground - if they lift, reduce depth or improve ankle mobility

exercises.name: Romanian Deadlifts (RDLs)
exercises.description: Posterior chain exercise targeting hamstrings, glutes, and lower back - critical for running power and injury prevention
steps: Stand holding dumbbells in front of thighs, feet hip-width apart
Slight bend in knees (soft knees), shoulders back, core engaged
Hinge at hips by pushing hips back, lowering weights down front of legs
Keep back flat (neutral spine), chest up, weights close to legs
Lower until you feel strong hamstring stretch (typically to mid-shin)
Squeeze glutes and drive hips forward to return to standing
Think 'hips to wall behind you' on descent, 'hips to wall in front' on ascent
tips: This is a HIP HINGE, not a squat - knees stay in same position
Feel the stretch in hamstrings, not rounding in lower back
Keep weights skimming down and up legs - they should almost touch shins
Strong hamstrings and glutes prevent common running injuries
This exercise directly improves your running stride power
Don't go too heavy - perfect form is essential
exercises.easier: Use lighter weight (5-8 kg), reduce range of motion (stop at knees), or do single-leg RDL with body weight only
exercises.harder: Increase weight by 2-4 kg, add 2-second pause at bottom stretch, or do single-leg RDLs with dumbbells
warnings: Stop if feeling pain in lower back - should only feel hamstring stretch
Don't round back - maintain neutral spine throughout
If you can't feel hamstrings, reduce weight and focus on form

exercises.name: Bulgarian Split Squats
exercises.description: Unilateral leg strength exercise to correct imbalances and build single-leg power for running
steps: Stand 2-3 feet in front of bench, facing away from it
Place top of left foot on bench behind you (shoelaces down)
Hold dumbbells at sides (or hands on hips for bodyweight version)
Lower straight down by bending right knee until right thigh is parallel to floor
Keep torso upright, front knee tracking over toes
Drive through right heel to return to starting position
Complete all reps on right leg, then switch to left leg elevated
tips: Front leg does 90% of work - back leg is just for balance
Keep weight centered over front foot - don't lean forward excessively
This reveals and fixes left-right strength imbalances
Critical for running - every stride is single-leg
Start with bodyweight to master balance, add weight when stable
Front shin should stay relatively vertical
exercises.easier: Bodyweight only (no dumbbells), reduce depth, or hold onto wall for balance
exercises.harder: Increase weight by 2 kg per hand, add 2 reps, or pause 2 seconds at bottom
warnings: Stop if front knee hurts - may need to adjust stance distance
Don't let front knee cave inward
This is challenging - it's OK if one leg is significantly weaker

exercises.name: Calf Raises (Standing)
exercises.description: Strengthen calves for push-off power in running and injury prevention
steps: Stand on edge of step with balls of feet on step, heels hanging off
Hold wall lightly for balance
Lower heels below step level to feel calf stretch - 2 seconds
Rise up onto toes as high as possible - 2 seconds
Hold at top for 1 second, squeezing calves
Lower back down with control
For final set, do single-leg (10 reps per leg) to identify imbalances
tips: Full range of motion is key - deep stretch to high rise
Control the eccentric (lowering) phase - this builds strength
Calves often get neglected but are crucial for running efficiency
Strong calves reduce risk of Achilles tendinitis
If cramping, ease off and stretch calves
exercises.easier: Do from floor (not elevated), or hold wall more firmly for balance
exercises.harder: Hold dumbbell in one hand, or do entire set single-leg, or add weight vest
warnings: Stop if experiencing Achilles pain
Don't bounce at bottom - smooth controlled movement

exercises.name: Lower Body & Hip Stretches
exercises.description: Essential post-strength stretching for recovery and flexibility maintenance
steps: Standing quad stretch: 30 seconds per leg, pull heel to glute
Standing hamstring stretch: 30 seconds per leg, foot on low step, lean forward from hips
Pigeon pose: 45 seconds per side for deep hip stretch
Low lunge (hip flexor stretch): 30 seconds per side
Seated butterfly stretch: 45 seconds, pressing knees toward floor
Supine figure-4 stretch: 30 seconds per side for glutes
Lying hamstring stretch: 30 seconds per leg, use strap or towel if needed
tips: Hips and legs need serious stretching after strength work
Breathe deeply - exhale helps you sink deeper into stretches
Hip flexibility is crucial for running efficiency and injury prevention
This complements your yoga practice
Consistency with stretching matters more than intensity
exercises.easier: Reduce hold times to 20 seconds, skip pigeon pose if uncomfortable
exercises.harder: Hold stretches 60 seconds each, add foam rolling for IT band and quads
warnings: Stop if experiencing sharp pain
Don't force hips beyond comfortable range

exercises.name: Vinyasa Flow with Core Emphasis
exercises.description: Power yoga session focusing on core strength, flexibility, and mind-body connection - complements running and strength training
steps: Sun Salutation A: 5 rounds to warm up - move with breath
Sun Salutation B: 5 rounds including warrior poses
Core sequence: Boat pose (30 sec hold), low plank to high plank transitions (10 reps), side plank each side (30 sec)
Standing balance series: Tree pose, warrior III, half moon - 45 seconds each side
Hip opening sequence: Lizard pose, pigeon pose, frog pose - 60 seconds each side
Cool down: Seated forward fold, supine twists, savasana (5 minutes)
tips: This session balances your strength training with flexibility work
Focus on breath - this is moving meditation
Core work in yoga translates directly to running efficiency
Balance poses improve proprioception for trail running
Let go of perfection - yoga is practice, not performance
exercises.easier: Skip warrior III and half moon, reduce hold times by 15 seconds, or do gentle flow instead of power yoga
exercises.harder: Hold poses 60 seconds each, add arm balances (crow pose), or increase to 90-minute session
warnings: Don't force flexibility - ease into poses gradually
Skip inversions if you have blood pressure concerns
Modify warrior III if you have balance issues

exercises.name: Tempo Run (Comfortably Hard Pace)
exercises.description: Threshold training to improve lactate clearance and race pace - key workout for half marathon prep
steps: Warm-up: 10 minutes easy jogging
4x100m strides: accelerate smoothly to 85% effort, walk back recovery
Tempo portion: 20 minutes at comfortably hard pace (80-85% max HR)
Pace should be: can speak short phrases but not full sentences
Target: approximately 15-20 seconds per km slower than your 5K race pace
Focus on maintaining even effort and good form
Cool-down: 10 minutes easy jogging, gradually slowing to walk
tips: Tempo runs are THE workout for half marathon improvement
Comfortably hard means: hard enough to be challenging, not so hard you're gasping
Even pacing is critical - don't start too fast
This teaches your body to clear lactate efficiently
You should finish feeling worked but not destroyed
Recovery between tempo runs is essential - 4-5 days minimum
exercises.easier: Reduce tempo portion to 15 minutes, or run at slightly easier pace (75-80% max HR)
exercises.harder: Increase tempo to 25-30 minutes, or add hills to tempo section
warnings: Stop if experiencing chest pain or extreme breathlessness
Don't do tempo runs on consecutive days
Skip if feeling fatigued or recovering from illness

exercises.name: Core Finisher Circuit (Post-Run)
exercises.description: Quick high-intensity core work to build running-specific strength when muscles are fatigued - mimics race conditions
steps: Plank hold: 45 seconds
Bicycle crunches: 30 total (15 per side, alternating)
Dead bugs: 20 total (10 per side)
Side plank: 30 seconds each side
Mountain climbers: 30 seconds maximum effort
Rest 60 seconds, repeat circuit 2 more times
tips: Doing core work when tired (post-run) teaches core to work when fatigued - exactly what happens in races
Maintain quality form even as you fatigue
This short circuit builds serious core endurance
Strong core prevents form breakdown in late race stages
Push hard but maintain control - sloppy reps don't count
exercises.easier: Reduce circuit to 2 rounds, or reduce hold/rep counts by 30%
exercises.harder: Add 4th round, increase plank holds to 60 seconds, or add weighted movements
warnings: Stop if lower back hurts during any movement
Don't sacrifice form for speed - control is key
Skip if extremely fatigued from tempo run

exercises.name: Full Body Recovery Stretching
exercises.description: Comprehensive post-workout stretching focusing on running muscles and areas worked this week
steps: Downward dog: 60 seconds - feel full body stretch
Low lunge with quad stretch: 45 seconds per side
Pigeon pose: 60 seconds per side - deep hip opener
Seated forward fold: 60 seconds - hamstrings and lower back
Supine spinal twist: 45 seconds per side
Happy baby pose: 60 seconds - hip and lower back release
Legs up the wall: 3-5 minutes - aids recovery and reduces leg fatigue
Savasana: 5 minutes - complete relaxation and integration
tips: This is recovery - not a test of flexibility
Breathe deeply through every stretch - 5-second inhales, 7-second exhales
Legs up wall is magic for runner recovery - it aids circulation
Use this time to mentally review your week's training
Savasana is when your body integrates the week's work - don't skip it
You earned this rest - take tomorrow (Saturday) completely off from structured training
exercises.easier: Reduce hold times to 30 seconds, skip legs up wall if uncomfortable
exercises.harder: Increase hold times to 90 seconds, add yin yoga poses
warnings: Never force any stretch beyond mild discomfort
Be gentle with hip stretches if you have any hip issues

exercises.name: Push-ups - Progressed Volume
exercises.description: Week 2 progression: adding reps and tempo variation
steps: Same form as Week 1
Set 1: 15 reps standard tempo
Set 2: 12 reps with 3-second eccentric (slow lowering)
Set 3: Max reps (shoot for 15+) standard tempo
Maintain perfect form - quality over quantity
tips: The slow eccentric set builds serious strength
This volume increase challenges muscles to adapt
By Week 8, you'll be doing 20+ reps easily
Strong upper body improves running arm drive efficiency
exercises.easier: Knee push-ups, or reduce to 10-12 reps per set
exercises.harder: Add weight vest, or try diamond push-ups for tricep emphasis
warnings: Stop if form breaks down significantly
Watch for wrist discomfort - may need hand position adjustment

weekly_schedule.focus: Recovery Week - Reduced Volume, Maintain Intensity
Half Marathon Specific - Long Runs Begin
